message: what do you usually drink? I'm a fan of most medium roasts, grinded fresh and made using a melitta cone. been meaning to try a chemex though
@Stammy I learned to drink coffee living in Hawaii, so now I'm stuck paying $40 a pound for it whenever I can find it.

I like medium roast coffee. I am a big fan of Starbucks. But the best  coffee I have ever had was from Brazil. A fellow undergrad brought it back with him after a trip to see his Grandparents. It was awesome.

I usually drink a combination of Engage energy drink and/or Monster Import, NOS, or Rockstar Recovery. I like coffee, but it upsets my stomach for some reason. I guess it doesn't have enough artificial chemicals.

Herbal tea for me :D flavors varies from anise seeds, Cinnamon, ginger (yeah Bengal spice!), Chamomile, lemon grass, peppermint, spearmint etc... Mate can be nice for the caffeine, but I prefer sublingual liquid B12  instead of caffeine for the kick.
I loved Açai with Guaraná and banana smoothie (without milk) when I was in Brazil. Unfortunately Acai seems pretty expensive in US... there is plenty of caffeine in Guarana too
Coffee is like liquor. The stronger it is the better. That's my theory at least. I'm underage so I wouldn't know :P
Kenya, ground and french pressed in the morning.
Blue Bottle Coffee, ground fresh. French press.
If you're in Seattle ever, you owe it to yourself to try Caffe Vitta. zomg best ever.
Also, Clover from Starbucks (there's one on Third and Market that has the machine) is amzing
Shade grown Mexican or other central America. I especially like the beans from the La Minita estate.
Double ristretto at Sicaffe
Anything dark and rich...and a lot of it please
Nicaraguan blend, not sure about the roast, semi-fresh ground? (was ground in the shop)
Turkish coffee is so good! Except I only have it occasionally. I have a simple espresso machine. Been making Americano lately.
A variety chosen from http://www.hasbean.co.uk/ usually to excess

I work from home most of the time, so I usually go either Lavazza for the plunger or Robert Timms for the instant. I head in to the city (Melbourne) once a week & usually grab my coffee from Puffing Billy Café in Belgrave, then from 1000 £ Bend once I'm in the city. I don't know what brands they use though.
turkish. even when not properly boiled (preferably on a gas burner somewhere in a desert/green place)
Monthly subscription for single origin coffee from Square Mile Coffee Roasters http://shop.squaremilecoffee.com/ filtered through an AeroPress

I believe the best balance between energy and self awareness can be obtained drinking high quality green tea. This is perfect to code. I am a bit too sensitive to coffee, it justs stress (and sometimes anger) me.
If anybody is looking for coffee in DC's Capitol Hill area, I highly recommend looking for Pound Coffee.  http://poundthehill.com

Roast your own.  Complete control of how dark, and it doesn't get any fresher.  Plus the smell of roasting coffee is wonderful--and completely different than brewing coffee.  Roaster+French Press = Love.  Plus, green unroasted coffee beans stay "fresh" for years...the clock starts ticking when you roast it.
Drinking a cup of freshly roasted Summatra right now!
Typical store-bought coffees (including $bucks) over-roast their coffees to increase their flavor over time, but that increases bitterness.
@brookshire whoa, I came from Indonesia but I don't enjoy Sumatran... have you tried kopi Luwak?

Espresso, cappuccino, or latte from my home espresso bar; Four Barrel or Sightglass espresso beans, 2 days after roasting, freshly ground, double shot of espresso. Often topped with steamed Clover milk, if I feel like a latte.
I brew or pull espresso from Counter Culture beans: http://counterculturecoffee.com
@0rion  you should try ginkgo and ginseng teas too ;)

And PLEASE: put sugar in your espresso! It's meant to be drank with sugar… It smoothens the natural bitterness allowing your taste buds to truly enjoy the flavor, not close up by the bitterness (main cause most people don't appreciate espressos).

Do yourself a favor and get to the nearest Nespresso boutique and ask for a "Roma". :)



You're welcome. ;)
All I have to say is: Nespresso Nespresso Nespresso! It's done *exactly* like the typical Portuguese espresso which, I should say, is by far the best espresso EVER! :)
Dude, if you're in San Francisco get Philz. Super friendly staff and they know how to make their joe.

I prefer the light flavored coffee for coding actually. Caffeine actually can be very counterproductive for me, I find that it allows me to easily distracted. I end up spending more time opening and closing my browser then actually programming.
snack&munch for coffee seems likes it could be a viable product according to this thread
AH! Anything made by an Australian barista. For some weird reason, Australia is to Coffee as France is to Cheese.

@ianlivingstone As much as I hate to admit it I think that last sentence describes me all too frequently. :(  I generally feel that I need coffee but the days I don't drink it I feel SO much better around 5pm, when I'm usually crashing on coffee days.  Tea ftw.
@thesteve Isn't that gevalia's business model?
As a good Argentinian I drink Mate a lot, much better than coffee! http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mate_(beverage)
I'll second @dion. Aeropress + fresh grounds from a local place for me. It makes _great_ coffee and it's quick so I can get back to work sooner :)
Aeropress inventor deserves the Nobel prize
Aeropress is awesome, though i haven't had the chance to use it in the past week :(
@bmelton could be, but I think there are places that deliver snack foods already as well. Does Gevalia have their own brand of beans? I am not too familiar with them.
I think they source their beans out, but they're delicious.  Better, they have a 'bean of the month' club too, where they send you coffees from new places.
@Stammy: bluebottle beans, and hario products (v60 etc).
What about beans inspired by hackers from around the world, even if you can't code with the best of them you can experience their buzz.
Aeropress beans from http://counterculturecoffee.com/, double ristrettos from http://octanecoffee.com - check it out if you're in Atlanta.
@unwrangle No, I haven't, but I'll look for it next time I'm buying some green beans.  Thanks!

Preparing (and ideally roasting) your own coffee is the only way to go for best results. Grind to order, never pre-grind. Try to get beans from a place that marks the roast date on the bag. Blue Bottle, Four Barrel and Ritual and my favorite little guy Bicycle Coffee all do this. Flavors bean flavors are at their peak 48 hours after roasting. Proper preparation can make a *huge* difference. Take a prep class at your local roaster. Four Barrel has an amazing one hour course for $10. Invest in a $20 Hario V60, a $20 hand grinder and a $20 scale and you can enjoy the most amazing coffee at home, work or on the road.  If you ever find yourself at SoMA Central in SF stop by ShortForm HQ and see our coffee lab. We are a little obsessed with coffee there. :-)
French pressed Gimme! Coffee beans.  http://www.gimmecoffee.com/
For me? Definitely 8-bit. <--- check out my avatar
We have a coffee shop in Birmingham which is "geek friendly", where I can easily spend upwards of 6 hours in. http://urbancoffee.co.uk
Barefoot coffee is the best in the South San Francisco Bay but get it now and enjoy it because they just got bought and it's only a matter of time before quality nosedives.
url: http://barefootcoffee.com
French pressed Pleasant Morning Buzz (from Whole Foods). As a side note, I'm happy to not read hundreds of people saying they drink Starbucks.
